title: 111_hr1943
content: The "Tax Equity Act of 2009" is the short title of this Act. It includes regional cost-of-living adjustments in individual income tax rates. The "Tax Equity Act of 2009" includes regional cost-of-living adjustments in individual income tax rates, with a method for making these adjustments. The "Tax Equity Act of 2009" includes regional cost-of-living adjustments in individual income tax rates, with a method for making these adjustments. The minimum and maximum dollar amounts for each rate bracket are multiplied by the applicable multiplier for the statistical area where the individual's primary residence is located. The rate for each bracket is adjusted accordingly, and the tax amount is also adjusted to reflect these changes. The "Tax Equity Act of 2009" includes regional cost-of-living adjustments in individual income tax rates. The Secretary determines applicable multipliers for each statistical area annually. If an amount is not a multiple of $50, it is rounded to the nearest multiple. The "Tax Equity Act of 2009" includes cost-of-living differentials for statistical areas in individual income tax rates. Applicable multipliers are determined annually by the Secretary based on specific criteria. The cost-of-living differential for each statistical area is calculated as a percentage. The "Tax Equity Act of 2009" includes cost-of-living differentials for statistical areas in individual income tax rates. The Secretary of Labor determines and publishes a cost-of-living index for each statistical area annually based on market prices. The Tax Equity Act of 2009 includes cost-of-living differentials for statistical areas in individual income tax rates. The market prices used are selected based on the methodology used by the Secretary of Labor in developing the Consumer Price Index for All Urban Consumers. The term 'statistical area' refers to metropolitan statistical areas defined by the Secretary of Commerce and portions of states not within those areas. The amendment made by the Tax Equity Act of 2009 applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 2009. A transition rule allows for the prescribing of applicable multipliers for taxable years beginning in 2010 one year after the enactment of the Act.
